item.title: 10 Reasons Startups Prefer Node.js over .NET
item.description: I’ve been a .NET software developer for my entire career, and I truly love the platform. I love the C# language, the productivity of the platform, and the ecosystem. But I’ve been dealing with an existential crisis for years now. I see how companies, especially startups, don’t seem to choose .NET as their platform of choice. They go to Node.js, Ruby, Python, or even Java as an alternative to ASP.NET. I even went as far as to write an article about it: Where did the Microsoft Tech Stack disappear?

item.title: Software Engineering Tips for CLMS Students
item.description: 0. Preamble This webpage is adapted from a slide deck I made for an orientation peer-mentoring session for the 2022 UW Computational Linguistics program. These are tips I’ve found helpful for my own workflow and productivity. Bear in mind though, everyone works different! Likewise, different work environments may impose different requirements and challenges. Some of what you see here may seem obvious, and some of these tips are very well-known. I hope at least one of these tips will help you, but take everything with a grain of salt.
item.author: (— Brian Kernighan, “The Elements of Programming Style”)

item.title: What Not to Recommend to Flatpak Users
item.description: Whenever I browse through the web, I find many “tips and tricks” from various blog writers, YouTubers and others who recommend users to take steps that either they aren’t supposed to, or have better alternatives. In this article, I will go over some of those steps you should not be taking and explain why.

item.title: Community Event Signup
item.description: .NET Conf is a FREE, three-day, virtual developer event that celebrates the major releases of the .NET development platform. It is co-organized by the .NET community and Microsoft, and sponsored by the .NET Foundation along with our ecosystem partners. Organize a watch party and/or post-conference presentation for your community or Meetup group and get all the technical content, promotion, and SWAG needed to create your event. Your event can be virtual or in-person depending on your local area health guidelines.If you plan to host an in-person watch party or event in a city with a Microsoft Reactor location, we can connect you with the Reactor space to serve as your venue.The .NET Conf team will provide the following for Hosts organizing events happening from November 8, 2022 through January 31, 2023:- Promotion of your event through #dotnetconf hashtag. - Promotion of your event on the .NET Conf local events page (https://dotnetconf.net).  - Technical content and a hands-on workshop. - Artwork to present and promote your local group/s. - SWAG for you and your attendees! How to Participate:- Coordinate a .NET Conf 2022 event for your local community or Meetup group. - Title your event with ".NET Conf 2022 [Name of your community group/location]". *Note: This form allows the request of both speakers and streaming support for virtual .NET Conf 2022 events. These are limited resources and provided based on support team availability on a “first-come-first-served" basis. Thus, we cannot guarantee every speaker and streaming request submitted for virtual events.

item.title: Microsoft Teams’ Infrastructure and Azure Communication Services’ Journey to .NET 6
item.description: Microsoft Teams’ infrastructure team, or Intelligent Conversation and Communications Cloud (IC3), aspires to be the industry leading platform with reliable and high-quality audio and video calling, meetings, and chat experiences that work any time, from anywhere, on any device. A key element of our platform evolution is the migration from .NET Framework to the latest version of .NET LTS, currently .NET 6.

item.title: Azure DevOps Podcast: Scott Hunter: Microsoft’s Azure & .NET Strategy- Episode 211
item.description: Topics of Discussion: [2:27] What are some things happening and that have happened at Microsoft that we may not be aware of? [7:25] Scott talks about some of the upcoming developments he is excited about that will make using the cloud in the future even better. [9:00] Scott’s favorite part of that whole journey was that reboot, learning from the shifts and the ebbs of the industry and, asking how to make .NET the right product for that next wave. [12:20] Scott also talks more about Microsoft's strategy with Azure & .NET. [27:41] Scott gives a preview of the Azure Dev CLI. [30:52] What is the difference in strategies between Azure and .NET, and how do we bring those together? [36:59] What are the big things that we need to put on our calendar for this fall? &nbsp; Mentioned in this Episode: — New video podcast! (Sponsor) — Available on Amazon! — Follow to stay informed about future events! programming@palermo.net &nbsp; Want to Learn More? Visit for show notes and additional episodes.

item.title: Getting started with OpenTelemetry Metrics in .NET. Part 2: Instrumenting the BookStore API
item.description: In this 2 part series-post I’m going to show you how to use OpenTelemetry to generate custom metrics and how to visualize those metrics using Prometheus and Grafana. In part 2 I’ll be showing you how to add OpenTelemetry Metrics on a real life .NET app and how to visualize those metrics using Prometheus and Grafana.
